facts.text: Rampur Distillery Company Ltd. is a manufacturer of industrial alcohol.

anchor.surface_text: The Rampur Distillery Company Ltd.---hereinafter called the Rampur Company----is a manufacturer of industrial alcohol.

facts.text: In 1943 the Rampur Company appointed Govan Brothers its managing agent for 20 years.

anchor.surface_text: In 194.3 the Rampur Company appointed Govan Brothers its managing agent for 20 years.

facts.text: In July 1946 a group of persons referred to as the Dalmia Group assumed control over Govan Brothers.

facts.text: By virtue of s. 330 of the Companies Act, 1956, the managing agency of the Rampur Company was to expire on August 15, 1960, unless re-appointed.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1959 the Rampur Company reappointed Govan Brothers, Managing Agent for ten years with effect from August 15, 1960, and applied to the Central Government

facts.text: The Central Government granted extension for five years under s. 326 of the Companies Act with effect from August 15, 1960.

facts.text: In May 1964 the police lodged criminal proceedings against V.H. Dalmia and 23 others in the Court of the District Magistrate, Delhi.

facts.text: On September 23, 1964, the Rampur Company passed resolution appointing Govan Brothers Managing Agent for five years from August 15, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On September 23, 1964, the Rampur Company passed another resolution appointing Govan Brothers Managing Agent for five years with effect from August 15, 1965, and applied to the Central Government

facts.text: Company Law Board extended the tenure of Govan Brothers till March 31, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The Campany Law Board extended the tenure of Govan Brothers till March 31, 1967. Another application by the Rampur Company dated August 25, 1966 for extension of the term of the managing agency

facts.text: Application by Rampur Company dated August 25, 1966 for extension upto August 1970 was rejected by the Company Law Board.

anchor.surface_text: Another application by the Rampur Company dated August 25, 1966 for extension of the term of the managing agency upto August 1970 was rejected by the Board.

facts.text: On June 10, 1967, Rampur Company moved petition in Delhi High Court to quash Board's decision.

anchor.surface_text: The Rampur Company then moved a petition in the High Court of Delhi on June 10, 1967, for an order quashing the decision of the Board and for an order extending the term of the managing agency

facts.text: Single Judge of High Court granted the petition.

anchor.surface_text: A single Judge of the High Court granted the petition holding that the managing agent was a private limited companypany and the reasons for failure to extend the managing agency

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court set aside single Judge order and remitted for fresh decision.

facts.text: After remand, learned Judge dismissed the writ petition.

facts.text: High Court in Letters Patent Appeal set aside the dismissal and directed Board to consider post-1947 conduct.

issues.text: Whether, despite the present tense in section 326(2)(b), past acts and conduct can be ignored in determining if a managing agent is a fit and proper person?

anchor.surface_text: The section uses the present tense. The satisfaction must be with reference to the three conditions existing in praesenti., but in adjudging whether a person is fit and proper to be appoint past actings and conduct cannot be ignored. In considering whether a person is fit to be appointed a managing agent the Board is not restricted to a consideration of his acts, conduct and activities proximate to the date of the application the Board has to consider his acts and activities past and present,

issues.text: Whether the power under section 326(2) of the Companies Act is administrative/subjective or quasi-judicial/objective, requiring compliance with natural justice?

anchor.surface_text: The Board apparently restricted itself to the findings recorded by the Commission headed by Mr. Justice Vivian Bose relating to the dealings of V.H. Dalmia with the companies of which he was a director between the years 1945 and 1947. The criticism by the Commission of the conduct of V.H. Dalmia, suggested that there were serious grounds for complaint against him, but these observations related to acts and omissions many years before the date on which the application was made.

issues.text: Whether the satisfaction of the Board under section 326(2) is immune from judicial review or can be challenged if based on irrelevant materials or ignoring relevant ones?

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General appearing for the Union of India contended that by the use of the expression in its opinion occurring in s. 326(2)(b) of the Companies Act, it is meant that the subjective satisfaction of the Central Government is determinative of the question whether the proposed person is fit and proper to be appointed managing agent... We are unable to agree.

holdings.text: Past acts and conduct cannot be ignored in determining whether a person is fit and proper to be appointed managing agent under s.326(2)(b), despite present tense; Board must consider past and present acts, shareholder interests, public interests.

anchor.surface_text: The section uses the present tense. The satisfaction must be with reference to the three conditions existing in praesenti., but in adjudging whether a person is fit and proper to be appoint past actings and conduct cannot be ignored. In considering whether a person is fit to be appointed a managing agent the Board is not restricted to a consideration of his acts, conduct and activities proximate to the date of the application the Board has to consider his acts and activities past and present, the interest of the share-holders and the general interests of the public in allowing the management to be continued by the Directors of the Company and other circumstances which have a bearing on the question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section uses present tense but fitness assessment requires holistic review of past and present conduct, public/shareholder interests to fulfill statutory purpose.

holdings.text: Power under s.326(2) of Companies Act is quasi-judicial, not administrative; requires duty to act judicially, enquiry per natural justice, objective appraisal of relevant materials, ignoring irrelevant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of power restrictive of rights, implies investigation and judicial approach; satisfaction must be objective based on relevant facts.

holdings.text: Company Law Board's refusal vitiated as it restricted consideration to 1945-47 Bose Commission findings on V.H. Dalmia, ignoring subsequent conduct, company progress, pending proceedings, public/shareholder interests.

anchor.surface_text: The Board apparently restricted itself to the findings recorded by the Commission headed by Mr. Justice Vivian Bose relating to the dealings of V.H. Dalmia with the companies of which he was a director between the years 1945 and 1947. The criticism by the Commission of the conduct of V.H. Dalmia, suggested that there were serious grounds for complaint against him, but these observations related to acts and omissions many years before the date on which the application was made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board failed to review all relevant circumstances including post-1947 conduct and other factors required for comprehensive fitness assessment.

holdings.text: Satisfaction under s.326(2) reviewable by courts if based on misapprehension of conditions, irrelevant materials, or ignoring relevant materials; not immune even if subjective in form.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfaction concerns objective facts; courts examine if conditions existed or decision perverse; jurisdiction not excluded for errors in process.

holdings.text: High Court correct in directing Board to reconsider post-1947 conduct of V.H. Dalmia and all relevant factors for fitness under s.326.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court's application of correct legal test to facts.

holdings.text: Power under s.326 differs from s.237(b); former quasi-judicial, latter administrative/subjective.

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General appearing for the Board invited our attention to the judgment in The Barium Chemicals Ltd. and Anr. v. The Company Law Board and Others 1 . But in that case Hidayatullah and Shelat, JJ., held that the action of the Board under s. 237 b was administrative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedents based on statutory context and power nature.

holdings.text: Appeals dismissed; Rampur Company's appeal fails as High Court correctly held Board must consider entire conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal filed by the Rampur Company must therefore fail. It must, however be pointed out that the time during which the managing agency of Govan Brothers is to remain in operation is fast running out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies holdings to dispose case upholding High Court direction for reconsideration.
